column1: DHCP Request
column2: Sent by the DHCP client to ask the server to lease the IPv4 address listed in the Offer message.

column1: DHCP Acknowledgement
column2: Sent by the DHCP server to assign the address, and to list the mask, default router, and DNS server IP addresses

column1: DHCP Offer
column2: Sent by a DHCP server to offer to lease to that client a specific IP address (and inform the client of its other parameters)
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: DHCP Discover
column2: Sent by the DHCP client to find a willing DHCP server

column2: A network topology in which subnets of network X are separated by subnets of some other classful network

column1: What's a contiguous IP network?
column2: A network topology in which subnets of network X are not separated by subnets of any other classful network

column1: How does autosummarization work?
column2: Autosummarization is a routing protocol feature in which a router that sits at the boundary between different classful networks will automatically advertise a route for one entire classful network into the other classful network, and vice versa.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What happens if you configure the RIP process with the command maximum-paths 1?
column2: Setting the value to 1 disables ECMP, so that RIP places only the first-learned equal-metric route into the routing table.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What happens when you use the passive-interface interface command when configuring RIP?
column2: The RIP process will no longer sends RIP updates out that interface. RIP will still process any received updates and will still advertise about the connected subnet.

column1: What happens when you enable RIP on an interface?
column2:
The router sends routing updates out the interface.
The router listens for and processes incoming updates on that same interface.
The router advertises about the subnet connected to the interface.

column1: How does the RIP network command work?
column2: The network command takes one parameter: a classful IP network that identifies which interfaces RIP will be enabled on.

column2: The practice of advertising a failed route with an infinite metric.

column1: What's split horizon?
column2: Never advertise a route out the same interface it was learned on.

column1: Describe the concept of distance vector routing protocols
column2: The routers learn three important facts related to each route: the destination subnet, the distance (that is, the routing protocol metric), and the vector (that is, the link and next-hop router to use as part of that route).
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column2: How long it takes for all routers to learn about a change in the network and update their IPv4 routing tables

column1: What is Carrier Grade NAT (CGN)?
column2: With CGN, instead of giving user networks their own public IPv4 addresses, a user’s private IPv4 address is translated using NAT to another private IPv4 address to connect to its provider’s network. The ISP typically uses an RFC 6598 address
column3: IPv6 Fundamentals: A Straightforward Approach to Understanding IPv6, 2nd Edition

column1: What's a floating static route?
column2: A floating static route floats or moves into and out of the IP routing table depending on whether the better (lower) administrative distance route learned by the routing protocol happens to exist currently.

column1: What is the job of the bandwith command?
column2: The bandwidth command is only there to communicate the speed of the interface to higher level protocols. It does not affect the actual speed of the interface.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's the purpose of the Aux port on a Cisco router?
column2: The Aux port typically serves as a means to make a phone call to connect into the router to issue commands from the CLI.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's the job of the clock rate command?
column2: This command tells that router the speed at which to transmit bits on a serial link
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: Formula to calculate the number of hosts per IPv4 network
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What does the counter runts mean when running the command show interfaces?
column2: Frames that did not meet the minimum frame size requirement (64 bytes, including the 18-byte destination MAC, source MAC, type, and FCS).
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What does the counter giants mean when running the command show interfaces?
column2: Frames that exceed the maximum frame size requirement (1518 bytes, including the 18-byte destination MAC, source MAC, type, and FCS).
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What does the counter late collisions mean when running the command show interfaces?
column2: The subset of all collisions that happen after the 64th byte of the frame has been transmitted. (In a properly working Ethernet LAN, collisions should occur within the first 64 bytes; late collisions today often point to a duplex mismatch.)
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What is the input errors counter of an interface?
column2: A total of many counters, including runts, giants, no buffer, CRC, frame, overrun, and ignored counts.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's a De jure standard?
column2: These standards have been approved by an officially recognized body whose job is to standardize protocols and other aspects of networking.
column3: The Illustrated Network, 2nd Edition

column1: What serial port settings do you need to set when connecting to the console port of a Cisco device?
column2:
9600 bits/second
No hardware flow control
8-bit ASCII
No parity bits
1 stop bit
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What is VTP?
column2: VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP). VTP is a Cisco proprietary protocol running on switches which is used to synchronize VLANs configured with other switches.

column1: What's the job of the access layer in the three-tier design?
column2: Provides a connection point (access) for end-user devices. Does not forward frames between two other access switches under normal circumstances.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's the job of the distribution layer in the three-tier design?
column2: Provides an aggregation point for access switches, providing connectivity to the rest of the devices in the LAN, forwarding frames between switches, but not connecting directly to end-user devices.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's the job of the core layer in the three-tier design?
column2: Aggregates distribution switches in very large campus LANs, providing very high forwarding rates for the larger volume of traffic due to the size of the network.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's the formula to calculate the number of links for a full-mesh topology?
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's a star topology?
column2: A design in which one central device connects to several others
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: How do you separate interfaces of a switch into multiple broadcast domains?
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's a broadcast domain?
column2: An Ethernet broadcast domain is the set of devices to which a broadcast is delivered.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: How many collision domains do you get with a switch?
column2: LAN switches place each separate interface into a separate collision domain.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's a collision domain?
column2: A collision domain is the set of NICs and device ports for which if they sent a frame at the same time, the frames would collide.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition

column1: What's SPAN?
column2: SPAN (Switched Port Analyzer) - A method of collecting traffic received on a switch port or a VLAN and sending it to specific destination ports on the same switch.
column3: CCIE Routing and Switching v5.0 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Fifth Edition

column1: Which bit in the Ethernet MAC address is set for multicast frames?
column2: The I/G bit, which signifies whether the address represents an individual device or a group of devices

column1: What would increasing counts of deferred frames on an interface indicate?
column2:
That the interface is running in half-duplex mode.
Deferred means that it chose to wait before sending frames because it was currently receiving a frame.

column1: What's the native VLAN?
column2: 802.1Q defines one special VLAN ID as the native VLAN (defaulting to use VLAN 1). By definition, 802.1Q simply does not add an header to frames in the native VLAN.

column1: How does switches handle frames with an unknown destination MAC address?
column2: Switches flood unknown unicast frames. Flooding means that the switch forwards copies of the frame out all ports, except the port on which the frame was received.

column1: How does a switch build its MAC address table?
column2: Switches build the address table by listening to incoming frames and examining the source MAC address in the frame.

column2: SSH encrypts all data exchange, including login passwords; Telnet encrypts nothing.

column1: What's a connectionless protocol?
column2: A protocol that does not require an exchange of messages and that does not require a pre-established correlation between two endpoints.
column3: CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide, First Edition
column5: Chapter 5. Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications

column1: What's a connection-oriented protocol?
column2: A protocol that requires an exchange of messages before data transfer begins, or that has a required pre-established correlation between two endpoints.

column5: Chapter 5. Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications

column2: With the TCP connection termination (FIN bit)
